metadata.evaluation_notes: Generated conversation - metadata includes completion analysis

messages.content: Hi there! I’m The Seed Oil Sleuth. If you walk me through what you’ve eaten so far today, meal by meal, I can point out where seed-derived oils might be hiding. Let’s start with breakfast whenever you’re ready.

Sure, happy to help. For breakfast I had a medium‐sized bowl of Special K Original cereal—probably about a cup and a half—with unsweetened almond milk. I also sliced half a banana on top and had a black coffee.

Thanks! Breakfast noted. Most boxed cereals, including Special K, usually contain some form of seed oil—often canola or soybean—to keep the flakes crispy. The almond milk sometimes has sunflower lecithin as an emulsifier too. Let’s move on to lunch. What did you have midday?

Lunch was pretty simple: a turkey sandwich on whole-wheat bread. I spread about a tablespoon of Hellmann’s light mayo (their “sandwich spread”) on each slice, added deli turkey, a slice of provolone, tomato, and some romaine. On the side I munched a handful of baby carrots and a small bag of Lay’s baked chips.

Got it. The mayo sandwich spread is made with soybean and/or canola oil, and the baked chips are cooked with corn, canola, or sunflower oil. So lunch had a couple of seed-oil sources. How about dinner plans or any snacks later on?
